references.B85STE01NAUS: Stebbins, R. C. 1985. A Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xiv + 336 pp.
references.A63FIT01NAUS: Fitch, H. S. 1963. Natural history of the racer Coluber constrictor. Univ. Kans. Publ. Mus. Nat. Hist. 15(8):351-468.
references.A94PLU01NAUS: Plummer, M. V., and J. D. Congdon. 1994. Radiotelemetric study of activity and movements of racers (COLUBER CONSTRICTOR) associated with a Carolina Bay in South Carolina. Copeia 1994:20-26.
references.A86COR01NAUS: Corn, P.S., and R.B. Bury. 1986. Morphological variation and zoogeography of racers (COLUBER CONSTRICTOR) in the Central Rocky Mountains. Herpetologica 42:258-264.
references.B82COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1982. Amphibians and reptiles in Kansas. Second edition. Univ. Kansas Mus. Nat. Hist., Pub. Ed. Ser. 8. xiii + 356 pp.
references.B81VOG01NAUS: Vogt, R. G. 1981. Natural history of amphibians and reptiles of Wisconsin. Milwaukee Public Museum. 205 pp.
references.B82HAM01NAUS: Hammerson, G. A. 1982. Amphibians and reptiles in Colorado. Colorado Division of Wildlife, Denver. vii + 131 pp.
references.B73BRO01NAUS: Brown, W. S. 1973. Ecology of the racer, Coluber constrictor mormon (Serpentes, Colubridae), in a cold temperate desert in northern Utah. Ph.D. thesis, Univ. Utah, Salt Lake City.
references.B89ERN03NAUS: Ernst, C. H., and R. W. Barbour. 1989. Snakes of eastern North America. George Mason Univ. Press, Fairfax, Virginia. 282 pp.
references.B72MIN01NAUS: Minton, S. A., Jr. 1972. Amphibians and reptiles of Indiana. Indiana Academy Science Monographs 3. v + 346 pp.
references.B80BAXUSGP: Baxter, G., and M. Stone.  1980.  Amphibians and reptiles of Wyoming. Wyoming Game and Fish Department, Cheyenne, Wyoming, USA.
references.A78WIL01NAUS: Wilson, L. D. 1978. Coluber constrictor. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 218.1-218.4.
references.B90COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1990. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Circular No. 19. 41 pp.
references.B82SMI01NAUS: Smith, H.M. and E.D. Brodie, Jr. 1982. Reptiles of North America. Golden Press, NY. 240pp.
references.A76BRO02NAUS: Brown, W. S., and W. S. Parker. 1976. Movement ecology of Coluber constrictor near communal hibernacula. Copeia 1976:225-242.
references.B02STJUSGP: St John, A.  2002.  Reptiles of the Northwest. Lone Pine Publishing, Auburn, Washington, USA.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.A91ROS01NAUS: Rosen, P. C. 1991. Comparative ecology and life history of the racer (COLUBER CONSTRICTOR) in Michigan. Copeia 1991:897-909.
references.A81FIT02NAUS: Fitch, H.S., W.S. Brown, and W.S. Parker. 1981. Coluber mormon, a species distinct from C. constrictor. Trans. Kansas Acad. Sci. 84:196-203.
references.B70FIT01NAUS: Fitch, H. S. 1970. Reproductive cycles of lizards and snakes. Univ. Kansas Museum Natural History Miscellaneous Publication 52:1-247.
references.B83NUS01NAUS: Nussbaum, R. A., and E. D. Brodie, Jr. and R. M. Storm. 1983. Amphibians and Reptiles of the Pacific Northwest. University Press of Idaho. 332 pp.
references.A84GRE03NAUS: Greene, H. W. 1984. Taxonomic status of the western racer,COLUBER CONSTRICTOR MORMON. J. Herpetol. 18:210-211.

habitat_description:
This species expands from the Canadian border south to Mexico and Guatemala, while rare in western Mexico and the southwestern United States. It is not common in New Mexico with occurrences reported only in grasslands, brushlands and woodlands of the northeastern part of the state and the Rio Grande Valley. The racer uses rocks, deadfall, and wood from old houses or corrals as cover (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Stebbins (2003) described the racer to prefer open habitats, meadows, prairies, sagebrush flats, open chaparral, pinon/juniper woodlands, and forest glades. Absent from extremely dry areas and high mountains. Its range expands from southern British Columbia, southern Saskatchewan, Wisconsin, Michigan, southern Ontario, New York, and southern Maine southward in the United States to southern California, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, the Gulf Coast, and southern Florida, and southward through northeastern, central, into southern Mexico to Guatemala and Belize.

NW	-forest glades, riparian zones.
UM	
NE	
SW-	open habitats, meadows, prairies, sagebrush flats, open chaparral, pinon/juniper woodlands, and streamsides.
GP	-Semi agricultural areas, plateaus, prairies, meadows.
